data.title: Will Barton pop quiz: Raptors guard on Nikola Jokić, The People’s Champ and more
data.meta_description: From his career-highs to his nickname ‘The People’s Champ,’ Barton answers our questions in this pop quiz.
data.text:
TORONTO — Things can move quickly when a player switches teams on the buyout market. For Will Barton, things moved so quickly that he missed his own reunion tour.

After a cameo appearance against Chicago, Barton’s next three games as a Raptor were two in Washington, where he just came from, and then one in Denver, where he spent parts of eight seasons. After the Washington Wizards waived him, the Raptors signed him.

“It happened so fast that I really didn’t get a chance to think about it,” Barton said. “It’s just crazy that I came from those two former teams, and then my first games were against them. It’s crazy.”

It continues on Tuesday, when Barton will play 669th regular-season game. The Nuggets are in town. Barton should get more of a chance to play in Toronto than he did in Washington, with Nick Nurse referring to him as the backup point guard on Monday. That perhaps stretches the definition of “point guard,” but Barton is likely to continue to get a shot to help prop a struggling bench.

He has 14 more games to make an impact as a Raptor. That’s just a blip in his career. In his 11th season, Barton has scored 7,566 points and assisted on 1,806 baskets in 16,954 minutes. On Monday, Barton sat down with The Athletic to take a quiz about some of the highlights.

(As always with the pop quizzes, thanks to Basketball Reference for the data. This interview has been edited for length, style and clarity.)

Three of your college teammates at Memphis ended up playing at least one NBA game in the regular season. Can you name them?

Tarik Black.

He was No. 1. He played 220.

I would say Adonis Thomas.

No. 2, he played six.

After that I would go D.J. Stephens.

Yes. Nailed it. Four games. Do you remember playing against Tarik?

Yeah. I dunked on Tarik one game. I definitely remember that. One-hander. I came through the lane, broke the defence down and he jumped at the last minute and I dunked on him.

Did you trash-talk him?

Of course. Me and him, we’re really good friends.

Can you name your coaches at Memphis who are currently coaching in the NBA. They’re both assistants. One of them has been a head coach before.

Glynn Cyprien. He was assistant coach, right?

Who?

Glynn Cyprien.

I don’t think he’s in the NBA. (Editor’s note: Cyprien never coached in the NBA, but he did coach Iowa and Memphis in the G League.)

You’re saying in the NBA now? Hold on.

They’re both former NBA players.

I do not remember.

Damon…

What? Noooooo. No. No. I do remember. Damon Stoudamire and Luke Walton.

Yep. I know Luke was a special case because he was only there during the (2011 NBA) lockout.

That’s the thing. Neither one of them was there for my freshman year. They were only there for my second year. Luke Walton and Damon Stoudamire, yeah.

(Editor’s note: During this interview, reports surfaced that Stoudamire, an assistant with the Celtics, was to become the next head coach at Georgia Tech. The news was later confirmed)

You’ve scored more than 7,500 points. Name the two players who were born in Baltimore who have scored more than you.

There are only two players?

Only two. Maybe some more than were raised in Baltimore, but only two were born in Baltimore.

S—. Is one Rudy Gay?

No. (Gay was born in Brooklyn but raised in Baltimore.)

Sam Cassell?

Yes. (Cassell scored 15,635 points).

Muggsy Bogues?

No.

I scored more points than Muggsy?

Yep. He’s an answer to the next question. (Bogues scored 6,858 points.) He’s one of two Baltimore-born players to play more minutes than you. Sam Cassell is the other.

So to score more. Sam and …

He played in the ‘90s.

Is it Reggie Lewis?

Yes.

I didn’t want to guess him because of what happened. (Lewis, the Boston forward, died due to a hypertrophic cardiomyopathy during an offseason practice in 1993. He was 27.)

It was tragic. I know.

Yeah. Man, I gotta remember that. I’m glad you asked me that. I need you to text me those two questions you just asked me. Those are the stats I can brag about back home.

Before you got into the league, the (40th-overall) pick that Portland eventually used to select you in 2012 was traded twice. Do you have any idea where it came from?

Who originally had that pick? No idea.

It was Minnesota’s pick.

Was that Brandon Roy?

No. They traded it with Jonny Flynn, Donatas Motiejūnas to Houston for Brad Miller, Nikola Mirotić, Chandler Parsons and the first-round pick that became Andre Roberson.

Wow. I never knew that.

And then your pick was traded to Portland in March 2012. Do you know who Houston got back for that?

No idea.

Marcus Camby.

You are second among all 2012 second-rounders in points scored.

Khris Middleton’s first.

Beat me to the question. There are three others, including Middleton, with more than 5,000 points.

Draymond Green and Jae Crowder.

Wow. You guys would have a pretty good five-man unit.

I’ve scored more total points than all of them, right?

Except Middleton.

Yeah, except Middleton. I’ve got more points than Draymond?

He doesn’t shoot that much. (Before Monday’s game in Phoenix, Green had 6,464 regular-season points.)

Damn.

I don’t know if you want to get into a trash-talking match with Draymond, but you could tell him that next time you’re playing.

Your first two baskets were in your second career game. Who were you playing in that game, and who assisted on your first 3?

Were we playing against Sacramento?

No.

Did Earl Watson give me the assist?

No.

Damian Lillard.

Right team, wrong guy. Another starter on that team. You just played against him.

We just played against him? Last week. I was with the Raptors?

He came off the bench for the Clippers.

*long pause*

Big forward. Play-making forward.

Nic Batum. F—— Nic Batum. Who were we playing against?

Houston.

How many times do you think you’ve scored 30 or more points in a game?

In my NBA career? Five.

Nine.

All right. Nice.

There was one former lottery pick who was traded with you from Portland to Denver.

Thomas Robinson.

Beat me to the question again. Do you remember all the guys in that trade?

Thomas Robinson. Me and Victor Claver for Arron Afflalo and picks?

I don’t actually have it written down so I’m gonna take your word for it. (Barton, Robinson, Claver and the first-round pick that became Malik Beasley went to Denver for Afflalo and Alonzo Gee.)

What is your career high, and who was it against?

My career high was 37 against the Bulls.

Yep. What can you tell me about the game-winning basket?

I hit a layup. Driving through defenders, off my right foot and got to the other side of the rim.

Do you know who contested it at the rim?

Man. It happened so fast. Robin Lopez?

Yep. Very good. Nine of your 13 buckets that night were assisted. Six players contributed to those nine assists.

Gary Harris.

Yep, he had three. He had the most.

Richard Jefferson.

Yep.

Nikola Jokić. How many more players do I need?

Three more.

Emmanuel Mudiay. *Pause* Juancho Hernangomez.

Very good.

I don’t know the last one.

Trey Lyles.

Ah, Trey!

A few weeks later, you had a career-high 10 assists. Only time that’s ever happened for you. Do you remember who it was against?

Nope.

Detroit.

Ah yeah, Detroit. I remember that.

Jokić didn’t play, so you needed some playmaking.

We lost that game.

I think you won, but I didn’t write it down. (The Nuggets won 103-84.) You found six guys for assists. There is some crossover from the last question. Who are the six?

Trey Lyles.

Yep.

Gary Harris.

Yep. Actually, no. You had no assists to Gary Harris that game.

I had no assists to Gary? Trey Lyles. Richard Jefferson.

No.

Damn. Juancho?

Nope.

Goddamn, who played that game? Did I say Trey Lyles already?

Three times now.

Did I get Mudiay one?

No. One guy who is still in Denver.

Oh, Jamal Murray.

Yep. One guy who you played last game, Lakers.

Who played on my team with the Lakers? Oh, Malik Beasley.

Yep.

Who else did I get an assist to that game? I have no idea.

All right. Some clues. One’s a big man who you actually just played on this road trip, too.

Who does he play with?

Clippers.

Who is it?

He has a brother who was in the NBA.

Mason (Plumlee).

Yep. The other two are Wilson Chandler and Darrell Arthur.

My guys.

Your eight most common teammates, the guys you have played the most games with, were all your teammates in Denver. The ninth wasn’t. Who is he?

Just who I shared the court with?

You would have played the same game, yes.

So he wasn’t just on the same team with me, but we shared the court together? S—, Damian Lillard?

Got it.

How many times do you think you have scored on a Jokić assist?

Psssst. A lot.

Correct. Give me a ballpark.

Two hundred?

*points up*

Four hundred?

That’s about it. You scored 393 times off his assist. He has assisted two players more than you.

Jamal Murray and Gary Harris.

Yes. Do you have any great Jokić stories?

Not really. He was just funny every day. A lot of people think he’s quiet, but he’s not. He talks a lot. He’s funny. He likes to laugh and joke. He’s got a great personality and sense of humour.

Last question. One of your nicknames listed on Basketball Reference is The People’s Champ. How did that happen?

Yep. I think after a game I said it in Portland. I was just saying how much the crowd was showing me love even though I don’t play a lot. I said, ‘I guess I’m just the people’s champ.’

Is there somebody you think of before yourself when I say, ‘The People’s Champ?’

Yeah, The Rock.

I figured. Were you a big Rock guy growing up?

Of course. Him and Stone Cold (Steve Austin), my favourite wrestlers ever.

Which one are you taking in a match?

Stone Cold.

(Top photo: Mark Blinch / Getty Images)
